Sir, I have the honour to report that on the night of Friday, January 6, 1933, two Bahrain fishing boats Ismail joliboats; returned to Maiiara^ and separately reported to the Amir and Police that they had been fired on by Persian Bellums on Fisht- Al-Jabrin. One shot had been fired at one of the boats on Wednesday morning and four shots at the other boats on Thursday before midday. A launch with a party of Police and the nakhudas of the fishing boats was sent out on Friday morning. Two Persian bellums, one empty and tae other loaded with sugar, were found anchored on the fisht. The first boat, the larger of the two was boarded and searched but no arms or ammunition were found. The nakhuda of this boat, said when the police arrived, that he knew the cause of their coming was owing to the shooting by the second bellumOn arriving at the small bellum, it was found that sacks of sugar were piled up round the sides with openings like loopholes and two men with rifles were seated in the cover of the sacks. The boat was boarded and the Nakhuda was arrested. He denied having fired any shots. Both nakhudas were brought back to Manamah by the police and a party of police was left on the bellums to bring them to Manamah, which they did on the following day. I, as police officer, investigated the matter and heard the statements of about a dozen witnesses. Eventually the nakhuda of the bellum admitted having fired a shot at the fishing boat on Wednesday but he denied having fired on the second boat on Thursday. The crew of the second fishing boat, whose evidence sounded reliable, all stated that the bellum had followed them, both sailing, for some distance, firing shots at them. The nakhuda of the bellum stated that he fired the one shot on Wednesday in order to make the fisher men bring him fish. This it appears is customary at Huwait but is not done in Bahrain waters and it is not a practice to be encouraged. 1 came to the conelusion that there was no poli tical motive in the shooting and after severely warning the Persian nakhuda I allowed the parties to agree to a compromise which was effected by the Persian nakhuda handinghanding over two bags of sugar to the Bahrain nakhudas. This fisht, part of which is above the sea at low tide is one of the many islands forming part of the Bahrain archipelago, a fact ^ which is universally admitted. On discussing the incident with Jl. Shaikh Hamad it was suggested that the Bahrain Government should erect a stone pillar on the fisht in order that there should be no doubt as to the ownership. I have the honour to be, Sir, Your obedient servant.Extract from A>iews for the period 1st to 15th January 1933. 20. Foliation: There is an incomplete foliation sequence and a complete foliation sequence. The complete foliation sequence is circled in pencil, in the top right corner of each folio. It begins on the front cover, on number 1, and runs through to 22, ending on the inside of the back cover.

mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence between the British Political Agent at Bahrain; the British Political Resident in the Persian Gulf at Bushire; Charles Dalrymple Belgrave, the Adviser to the Bahrain Government; and the India Office, London.The correspondence concerns an incident in January 1931 when two Tangistani boats opened fire on Bahraini fishing boats and a discussion to erect a stone pillar on Fasht al-Jārim where the incident occured in order to designate it as Bahraini territory. The remainder of the correspondence concern the looting of the steamship Star of Mexwhich ran aground at Rā’s al-Ḥadd on the coast of Oman in February 1947.
